column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=DRAINAGE.
#Text=A nurse is not, in her avocation, consulted as to
#Text=how to build a house-drain, and I see no reason
#Text=therefore why she should be burdened with details
#Text=of dry or wet removal of sewage, nor the course,
#Text=material, and shape of drains; these are the province
#Text=of the architect and sanitary engineer.
#Text=We may,
#Text=however, state, enpassant on such subjects, that when
#Text=her nose persistently, or even casually, suggests to
#Text=her that there is an offensive smell in a certain room
#Text=in the house in which she is nursing, she might think
#Text=of a gas-jet not turned off, of leaking gas or soil-pipes, or an old forgotten cesspool, or leaking drain,
#Text=and mention her suspicions to the doctor or to the
#Text=responsible head of the house.
#Text=But here, in my
#Text=opinion, her duty and responsibility end so far as
#Text=smells and drains are concerned.
#Text=Her duties with regard to what I may term the
#Text=drainage of the sick room include the disposal of:
#Text=
#Text=(1) Motions, urine, and clothes soiled with the
#Text=same, from the sick room
#Text=.
#Text=(2) Refuse, bits and ends of food, from the same
#Text=.
#Text=(3) Utensils used in the same
#Text=.
#Text=(4) Dust collected in sweeping the sick room.
